column2: III.
column3: three.

column2: I always considered my father--I speak of him in the past tense, because we are now separated for ever; because he is henceforth as dead to me as if the grave had closed over him--I always considered my father to be the proudest man I ever knew; the proudest man I ever heard of.
column3: I always considered my father-I speak of him in the past tense, because we are now separated for ever; because he is henceforth as dead to me as if the grave had closed over him-I always considered my father to be the proudest man I ever knew; the proudest man I ever heard of.

column2: His was not that conventional pride, which the popular notions are fond of characterising by a stiff, stately carriage; by a rigid expression of features; by a hard, severe intonation of voice; by set speeches of contempt for poverty and rags, and rhapsodical braggadocio about rank and breeding.
column3: His was not that conventional pride, which the popular notions are fond of characterising by a stiff, stately carriage; by a rigid expression of features; by a hard, severe intonation of voice; by set speeches of contempt for poverty and rags, and rhapsodical braggadocio about rank and breeding.

column2: My father's pride had nothing of this about it.
column3: My father's pride had nothing of this about it.

column2: It was that quiet, negative, courteous, inbred pride, which only the closest observation could detect; which no ordinary observers ever detected at all.
column3: It was that quiet, negative, courteous, inbred pride, which only the closest observation could detect; which no ordinary observers ever detected at all.

column2: Who that observed him in communication with any of the farmers on any of his estates--who that saw the manner in which he lifted his hat, when he accidentally met any of those farmers' wives--who that noticed his hearty welcome to the man of the people, when that man happened to be a man of genius--would have thought him proud?
column3: Who that observed him in communication with any of the farmers on any of his estates-who that saw the manner in which he lifted his hat, when he accidentally met any of those farmers' wives-who that noticed his hearty welcome to the man of the people, when that man happened to be a man of genius-would have thought him proud?

column2: On such occasions as these, if he had any pride, it was impossible to detect it.
column3: On such occasions as these, if he had any pride, it was impossible to detect it.

column2: But seeing him when, for instance, an author and a new-made peer of no ancestry entered his house together--observing merely the entirely different manner in which he shook hands with each--remarking that the polite cordiality was all for the man of letters, who did not contest his family rank with him, and the polite formality all for the man of title, who did--you discovered where and how he was proud in an instant.
column3: But seeing him when, for instance, an author and a new made peer of no ancestry entered his house together-observing merely the entirely different manner in which he shook hands with each-remarking that the polite cordiality was all for the man of letters, who did not contest his family rank with him, and the polite formality all for the man of title, who did-you discovered where and how he was proud in an instant.

column2: Here lay his fretful point.
column3: Here lay his fretful point.

column2: The aristocracy of rank, as separate from the aristocracy of ancestry, was no aristocracy for _him._ He was jealous of it; he hated it.
column3: The aristocracy of rank, as separate from the aristocracy of ancestry, was no aristocracy for underscore him.underscore He was jealous of it; he hated it.

column2: Commoner though he was, he considered himself the social superior of any man, from a baronet up to a duke, whose family was less ancient than his own.
column3: Commoner though he was, he considered himself the social superior of any man, from a baronet up to a duke, whose family was less ancient than his own.

column2: Among a host of instances of this peculiar pride of his which I could cite, I remember one, characteristic enough to be taken as a sample of all the rest.
column3: Among a host of instances of this peculiar pride of his which I could cite, I remember one, characteristic enough to be taken as a sample of all the rest.

column2: It happened when I was quite a child, and was told me by one of my uncles now dead--who witnessed the circumstance himself, and always made a good story of it to the end of his life.
column3: It happened when I was quite a child, and was told me by one of my uncles now dead-who witnessed the circumstance himself, and always made a good story of it to the end of his life.

column2: A merchant of enormous wealth, who had recently been raised to the peerage, was staying at one of our country houses.
column3: A merchant of enormous wealth, who had recently been raised to the peerage, was staying at one of our country houses.

column2: His daughter, my uncle, and an Italian Abbe were the only guests besides.
column3: His daughter, my uncle, and an Italian Abbe were the only guests besides.

column2: The merchant was a portly, purple-faced man, who bore his new honours with a curious mixture of assumed pomposity and natural good-humour.
column3: The merchant was a portly, purple faced man, who bore his new honours with a curious mixture of assumed pomposity and natural good humour.

column2: The Abbe was dwarfish and deformed, lean, sallow, sharp-featured, with bright bird-like eyes, and a low, liquid voice.
column3: The Abbe was dwarfish and deformed, lean, sallow, sharp featured, with bright bird like eyes, and a low, liquid voice.

column2: He was a political refugee, dependent for the bread he ate, on the money he received for teaching languages.
column3: He was a political refugee, dependent for the bread he ate, on the money he received for teaching languages.

column2: He might have been a beggar from the streets; and still my father would have treated him as the principal guest in the house, for this all-sufficient reason--he was a direct descendant of one of the oldest of those famous Roman families whose names are part of the history of the Civil Wars in Italy.
column3: He might have been a beggar from the streets; and still my father would have treated him as the principal guest in the house, for this all sufficient reason-he was a direct descendant of one of the oldest of those famous Roman families whose names are part of the history of the Civil Wars in Italy.

column2: On the first day, the party assembled for dinner comprised the merchant's daughter, my mother, an old lady who had once been her governess, and had always lived with her since her marriage, the new Lord, the Abbe, my father, and my uncle.
column3: On the first day, the party assembled for dinner comprised the merchant's daughter, my mother, an old lady who had once been her governess, and had always lived with her since her marriage, the new Lord, the Abbe, my father, and my uncle.

column2: When dinner was announced, the peer advanced in new-blown dignity, to offer his arm as a matter of course to my mother.
column3: When dinner was announced, the peer advanced in new blown dignity, to offer his arm as a matter of course to my mother.

column2: My father's pale face flushed crimson in a moment. He touched the magnificent merchant-lord on the arm, and pointed significantly, with a low bow, towards the decrepit old lady who had once been my mother's governess.
column3: My father's pale face flushed crimson in a moment. He touched the magnificent merchant lord on the arm, and pointed significantly, with a low bow, towards the decrepit old lady who had once been my mother's governess.

column2: Then walking to the other end of the room, where the penniless Abbe was looking over a book in a corner, he gravely and courteously led the little, deformed, limping language-master, clad in a long, threadbare, black coat, up to my mother (whose shoulder the Abbe's head hardly reached), held the door open for them to pass out first, with his own hand; politely invited the new nobleman, who stood half-paralysed between confusion and astonishment, to follow with the tottering old lady on his arm; and then returned to lead the peer's daughter down to dinner himself.
column3: Then walking to the other end of the room, where the penniless Abbe was looking over a book in a corner, he gravely and courteously led the little, deformed, limping language master, clad in a long, threadbare, black coat, up to my mother (whose shoulder the Abbe's head hardly reached), held the door open for them to pass out first, with his own hand; politely invited the new nobleman, who stood half paralysed between confusion and astonishment, to follow with the tottering old lady on his arm; and then returned to lead the peer's daughter down to dinner himself.

column2: He only resumed his wonted expression and manner, when he had seen the little Abbe--the squalid, half-starved representative of mighty barons of the olden time--seated at the highest place of the table by my mother's side.
column3: He only resumed his wonted expression and manner, when he had seen the little Abbe-the squalid, half starved representative of mighty barons of the olden time-seated at the highest place of the table by my mother's side.

column2: It was by such accidental circumstances as these that you discovered how far he was proud.
column3: It was by such accidental circumstances as these that you discovered how far he was proud.

column2: He never boasted of his ancestors; he never even spoke of them, except when he was questioned on the subject; but he never forgot them.
column3: He never boasted of his ancestors; he never even spoke of them, except when he was questioned on the subject; but he never forgot them.

column2: They were the very breath of his life; the deities of his social worship: the family treasures to be held precious beyond all lands and all wealth, all ambitions and all glories, by his children and his children's children to the end of their race.
column3: They were the very breath of his life; the deities of his social worship: the family treasures to be held precious beyond all lands and all wealth, all ambitions and all glories, by his children and his children's children to the end of their race.

column2: In home-life he performed his duties towards his family honourably, delicately, and kindly.
column3: In home life he performed his duties towards his family honourably, delicately, and kindly.

column2: I believe in his own way he loved us all; but we, his descendants, had to share his heart with his ancestors--we were his household property as well as his children.
column3: I believe in his own way he loved us all; but we, his descendants, had to share his heart with his ancestors-we were his household property as well as his children.

column2: Every fair liberty was given to us; every fair indulgence was granted to us.
column3: Every fair liberty was given to us; every fair indulgence was granted to us.

column2: He never displayed any suspicion, or any undue severity.
column3: He never displayed any suspicion, or any undue severity.

column2: We were taught by his direction, that to disgrace our family, either by word or action, was the one fatal crime which could never be forgotten and never be pardoned.
column3: We were taught by his direction, that to disgrace our family, either by word or action, was the one fatal crime which could never be forgotten and never be pardoned.

column2: We were formed, under his superintendence, in principles of religion, honour, and industry; and the rest was left to our own moral sense, to our own comprehension of the duties and privileges of our station.
column3: We were formed, under his superintendence, in principles of religion, honour, and industry; and the rest was left to our own moral sense, to our own comprehension of the duties and privileges of our station.

column2: There was no one point in his conduct towards any of us that we could complain of; and yet there was something always incomplete in our domestic relations.
column3: There was no one point in his conduct towards any of us that we could complain of; and yet there was something always incomplete in our domestic relations.

column2: It may seem incomprehensible, even ridiculous, to some persons, but it is nevertheless true, that we were none of us ever on intimate terms with him.
column3: It may seem incomprehensible, even ridiculous, to some persons, but it is nevertheless true, that we were none of us ever on intimate terms with him.

column2: I mean by this, that he was a father to us, but never a companion.
column3: I mean by this, that he was a father to us, but never a companion.

column2: There was something in his manner, his quiet and unchanging manner, which kept us almost unconsciously restrained.
column3: There was something in his manner, his quiet and unchanging manner, which kept us almost unconsciously restrained.

column2: I never in my life felt less at my ease--I knew not why at the time--than when I occasionally dined alone with him.
column3: I never in my life felt less at my ease-I knew not why at the time-than when I occasionally dined alone with him.

column2: I never confided to him my schemes for amusement as a boy, or mentioned more than generally my ambitious hopes, as a young man.
column3: I never confided to him my schemes for amusement as a boy, or mentioned more than generally my ambitious hopes, as a young man.

column2: It was not that he would have received such confidences with ridicule or severity, he was incapable of it; but that he seemed above them, unfitted to enter into them, too far removed by his own thoughts from such thoughts as ours.
column3: It was not that he would have received such confidences with ridicule or severity, he was incapable of it; but that he seemed above them, unfitted to enter into them, too far removed by his own thoughts from such thoughts as ours.

column2: Thus, all holiday councils were held with old servants; thus, my first pages of manuscript, when I first tried authorship, were read by my sister, and never penetrated into my father's study.
column3: Thus, all holiday councils were held with old servants; thus, my first pages of manuscript, when I first tried authorship, were read by my sister, and never penetrated into my father's study.

column2: Again, his mode of testifying displeasure towards my brother or myself, had something terrible in its calmness, something that we never forgot, and always dreaded as the worst calamity that could befall us.
column3: Again, his mode of testifying displeasure towards my brother or myself, had something terrible in its calmness, something that we never forgot, and always dreaded as the worst calamity that could befall us.

column2: Whenever, as boys, we committed some boyish fault, he never displayed outwardly any irritation--he simply altered his manner towards us altogether.
column3: Whenever, as boys, we committed some boyish fault, he never displayed outwardly any irritation-he simply altered his manner towards us altogether.

column2: We were not soundly lectured, or vehemently threatened, or positively punished in anyway; but, when we came in contact with him, we were treated with a cold, contemptuous politeness (especially if our fault showed a tendency to anything mean or ungentlemanlike) which cut us to the heart.
column3: We were not soundly lectured, or vehemently threatened, or positively punished in anyway; but, when we came in contact with him, we were treated with a cold, contemptuous politeness (especially if our fault showed a tendency to anything mean or ungentlemanlike) which cut us to the heart.

column2: On these occasions, we were not addressed by our Christian names; if we accidentally met him out of doors, he was sure to turn aside and avoid us; if we asked a question, it was answered in the briefest possible manner, as if we had been strangers.
column3: On these occasions, we were not addressed by our Christian names; if we accidentally met him out of doors, he was sure to turn aside and avoid us; if we asked a question, it was answered in the briefest possible manner, as if we had been strangers.

column2: His whole course of conduct said, as though in so many words--You have rendered yourselves unfit to associate with your father; and he is now making you feel that unfitness as deeply as he does.
column3: His whole course of conduct said, as though in so many words-You have rendered yourselves unfit to associate with your father; and he is now making you feel that unfitness as deeply as he does.

column2: We were left in this domestic purgatory for days, sometimes for weeks together.
column3: We were left in this domestic purgatory for days, sometimes for weeks together.

column2: To our boyish feelings (to mine especially) there was no ignominy like it, while it lasted.
column3: To our boyish feelings (to mine especially) there was no ignominy like it, while it lasted.

column2: I know not on what terms my father lived with my mother.
column3: I know not on what terms my father lived with my mother.

column2: Towards my sister, his demeanour always exhibited something of the old-fashioned, affectionate gallantry of a former age.
column3: Towards my sister, his demeanour always exhibited something of the old-fashioned, affectionate gallantry of a former age.

column2: He paid her the same attention that he would have paid to the highest lady in the land.
column3: He paid her the same attention that he would have paid to the highest lady in the land.

column2: He led her into the dining-room, when we were alone, exactly as he would have led a duchess into a banqueting-hall.
column3: He led her into the dining room, when we were alone, exactly as he would have led a duchess into a banqueting hall.

column2: He would allow us, as boys, to quit the breakfast-table before he had risen himself; but never before she had left it.
column3: He would allow us, as boys, to quit the breakfast table before he had risen himself; but never before she had left it.

column2: If a servant failed in duty towards _him,_ the servant was often forgiven; if towards _her,_ the servant was sent away on the spot.
column3: If a servant failed in duty towards underscore him,underscore the servant was often forgiven; if towards underscore her,underscore the servant was sent away on the spot.

column2: His daughter was in his eyes the representative of her mother: the mistress of his house, as well as his child.
column3: His daughter was in his eyes the representative of her mother: the mistress of his house, as well as his child.

column2: It was curious to see the mixture of high-bred courtesy and fatherly love in his manner, as he just gently touched her forehead with his lips, when he first saw her in the morning.
column3: It was curious to see the mixture of high bred courtesy and fatherly love in his manner, as he just gently touched her forehead with his lips, when he first saw her in the morning.

column2: In person, my father was of not more than middle height.
column3: In person, my father was of not more than middle height.

column2: He was very slenderly and delicately made; his head small, and well set on his shoulders--his forehead more broad than lofty--his complexion singularly pale, except in moments of agitation, when I have already noticed its tendency to flush all over in an instant.
column3: He was very slenderly and delicately made; his head small, and well set on his shoulders-his forehead more broad than lofty-his complexion singularly pale, except in moments of agitation, when I have already noticed its tendency to flush all over in an instant.

column2: His eyes, large and gray, had something commanding in their look; they gave a certain unchanging firmness and dignity to his expression, not often met with.
column3: His eyes, large and gray, had something commanding in their look; they gave a certain unchanging firmness and dignity to his expression, not often met with.

column2: They betrayed his birth and breeding, his old ancestral prejudices, his chivalrous sense of honour, in every glance.
column3: They betrayed his birth and breeding, his old ancestral prejudices, his chivalrous sense of honour, in every glance.

column2: It required, indeed, all the masculine energy of look about the upper part of his face, to redeem the lower part from an appearance of effeminacy, so delicately was it moulded in its fine Norman outline.
column3: It required, indeed, all the masculine energy of look about the upper part of his face, to redeem the lower part from an appearance of effeminacy, so delicately was it moulded in its fine Norman outline.

column2: His smile was remarkable for its sweetness--it was almost like a woman's smile.
column3: His smile was remarkable for its sweetness-it was almost like a woman's smile.

column2: In speaking, too, his lips often trembled as women's do.
column3: In speaking, too, his lips often trembled as women's do.

column2: If he ever laughed, as a young man, his laugh must have been very clear and musical; but since I can recollect him, I never heard it.
column3: If he ever laughed, as a young man, his laugh must have been very clear and musical; but since I can recollect him, I never heard it.

column2: In his happiest moments, in the gayest society, I have only seen him smile.
column3: In his happiest moments, in the gayest society, I have only seen him smile.

column2: There were other characteristics of my father's disposition and manner, which I might mention; but they will appear to greater advantage, perhaps, hereafter, connected with circumstances which especially called them forth.
column3: There were other characteristics of my father's disposition and manner, which I might mention; but they will appear to greater advantage, perhaps, hereafter, connected with circumstances which especially called them forth.

column2: IV.
column3: i v.

column2: When a family is possessed of large landed property, the individual of that family who shows least interest in its welfare; who is least fond of home, least connected by his own sympathies with his relatives, least ready to learn his duties or admit his responsibilities, is often that very individual who is to succeed to the family inheritance--the eldest son.
column3: When a family is possessed of large landed property, the individual of that family who shows least interest in its welfare; who is least fond of home, least connected by his own sympathies with his relatives, least ready to learn his duties or admit his responsibilities, is often that very individual who is to succeed to the family inheritance-the eldest son.
